Award.AwardTitle: mTERF Function and Control of Plant Respiration and Stress Tolerance
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plant survival and fecundity/productivity under stress conditions determine species distribution in nature as well as agricultural output. The long term goal of this research project is to define critical features of plant energy metabolism that determine stress survival. The specific focus of the research project is the control of respiration in plant mitochondria, which are critical energy generating organelles in all organisms. A better understanding of the regulation of mitochondrial components is needed to explain plant energy balance and biomass accumulation. Because respiratory activity is part of the equation determining plant productivity, understanding the control of plant respiration may enable targeted manipulation of respiration to enhance productivity, particularly under stress conditions.

Experiments will be performed to define the function of a class of proteins predicted to regulate plant mitochondrial gene expression known as mTERFs, for mitochondrial Transcription Termination Factors, using a combination of state-of-the-art biochemistry and genetics in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. The PI has demonstrated that mutation of an mTERF protein (SHOT1) targeted to plant mitochondria can enhance tolerance to high temperature stress apparently by limiting oxidative damage. Experiments will define the molecular mechanism of SHOT1 function, and go on to test how other mTERFs may also contribute to control of respiration and plant stress tolerance. The project will provide training in experimentation and communication for one postdoctoral scientist, one graduate student and two undergraduates for each year of the award. The PI will also engage in outreach activities to encourage teenage girls to consider science as a career option and to inform the public about the scientific basis of genetically modified plants. These talks will provide information in lay terms on the underlying biochemistry and molecular biology of GMOs so that individuals can make informed decisions about the technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research completed in this project has defined new aspects controlling biological energy generation in plants under both optimal and stress conditions. Almost all life on Earth depends on light energy from the Sun, which plant photosynthesis converts into the sugars that sustain living organisms. In virtually all cells, other than bacteria, specialized subcellular organelles called mitochondria are required to metabolize these sugars into ATP, the chemical that drives life processes. Mitochondria achieve this important task on a specialized inner mitochondrial membrane by a process called oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS). The OXPHOS machinery comprises multiple protein complexes (complexes I to V) that are constructed with proteins made both outside of mitochondria, encoded by genes in the cell nucleus, and proteins made within mitochondria, encoded by the organelle’s own DNA. Coordinating synthesis and functional assembly of this essential OXPHOS machinery is a complex process that requires multiple regulatory and accessory factors. Nuclear-encoded mTERF (mitochondrial transcription termination factors) proteins are one type of these regulatory factors, and they have emerged as involved in expression of mitochondrial genes by interacting with mitochondrial DNA or RNA. Completed research provides important insights into how mTERF proteins act in the proper function of plant mitochondria and in abiotic stress tolerance.

We have discovered, in our studies of the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana, that one mTERF protein, mTERF18/SHOT1, plays critical roles in the biogenesis of the OXPHOS machinery and in plant heat stress tolerance. Transgenic plant approaches, confocal microscopy, proteomics and advanced DNA sequencing techniques were used to compare wild-type plants to mutants defective in mTERF18/SHOT1. Results show that mTERF18/SHOT1 binds both mitochondrial DNA and to three homologs of the human ATAD3A protein, which is involved in organizing mitochondrial DNA and proteins into compact “nucleoids”. Disruption of nucleoid structure correlates with loss of proper mitochondrial function. The data also reveal that mTERF18/SHOT1 and ATAD3A homologs are critical for accumulation of OXPHOS complex I, emphasizing the close relationship between nucleoid organization and functional OXPHOS. In addition, nucleoid disorganization caused by defects in mTERF18/SHOT1 and ATAD3 leads to unique mitochondrial and cellular responses resulting in enhanced heat tolerance and reduced production of damaging reactive oxygen species. Defining the mechanisms leading to enhanced heat tolerance offer the possibility to understand how to develop plants better able to survive abiotic stress.

Further experiments to investigate factors contributing to the heat tolerance phenotype of mTERF18/SHOT1 mutants were also conducted. In addition to failure to assemble OXPHOS complex I, mutants defective in mTERF18/SHOT1 have reduced complex V, the enzyme responsible for ATP synthesis. To understand how specifically reducing complex V impacts other OXPHOS complexes and abiotic stress tolerance, plants with reduced complex V activity were created by suppressing the synthesis of ATP synthase subunit d. The plants with reduced complex V activity had normal levels of other OXPHOS complexes, and in contrast to mTERF18/SHOT1 mutants, had increased levels of reactive oxygen species and increased sensitivity to heat stress. These results indicate that complex V defects in mTERF18/SHOT1 mutants are not responsible for the enhanced heat stress tolerance. Notably mutants that cannot produce subunit d are not viable, emphasizing the overall importance of mitochondrial OXPHOS for plant development and growth.

To expand studies into other mitochondria-localized mTERF proteins, mutations in 10 other mTERF proteins were identified. Two of the mTERFs (mTERF15 and 21) are essential for plant development. None of these proteins seems to bind mitochondrial DNA, but mTERF21 interacts with the same ATAD3 proteins that were identified as binding SHOT1/mTERF18. Further molecular and biochemical characterizations are required to understand the exact function of mTERF21. The other mTERF mutants did not show any obvious growth defects, and therefore appear to have proper mitochondrial function. A number of double mutant combinations also did not show growth defects, indicating that many mitochondrial mTERFs have limited functions or highly redundant functions.

Results from this project emphasize the critical role of mitochondria in plant biology, as well as in all life on Earth. Although conversion of sun energy to the organic carbon compounds necessary for life depends on photosynthesis, without mitochondria further processing of this organic carbon energy is incomplete. Plants have conserved and unique mechanisms involved in regulating mitochondrial function and defining these processes will be key to future efforts directed to understanding plant responses to the environment, constraints on species distribution and improving crop production.
